comment.author: 45586426@N06
comment._content: Three Douglas A4D-1 Skyhawks in echelon right copied from a damage creased monochrome print. All wearing tail code 7F of NAS Alameda (formerly of NAS Oakland) Naval Air Reserve Training Unit. With large Red/Orange ‘Dayglo’ painted areas on nose tail and wings. Picture date deduced to be 1961 from recorded history of one of the aircraft portrayed. Prior to 1970, reserve aircraft belonged to the local NARTU or Reserve Naval Air Station. Except for those squadrons on active duty, no reserve squadron "owned" their aircraft, as they were assigned to the NARTU/Station. In 1970, during the reorganization of the reserves into the "Reserve Force" concept, each new squadron was made independent of NARTU (later called NAR), and assigned either to CVWR-20 or CVWR-30. All squadrons were then made in the image of active duty units, with the reserve unit Commanding Officer owning the aircraft and reporting to the CAG. (Courtesy the ‘A-4 Skyhawk Association’) A representative picture of an NAS Oakland Reserve Skyhawk from 1961: www.a4skyhawk.org/content/a4d-1-nas-oakland-vf-873 Variant: A4D-1 Custodian: NAS Oakland BuNo: 123456 Modex: 7F-125 Location: NAS Oakland / NAS Alameda Date: 1961 Photo Credit: Naval Aviation News MAY61 NAN photo of a pilot beginning transition into jets, A4D-1, and also moving from Oakland to Alameda (Courtesy the ‘A-4 Skyhawk Association’) From the four numbers on each tailplane the aircraft type and Navy serial numbers are: A4D-1 142234 Modex 126 A4D-1 142146 Modex 115 A4D-1 142168 Modex unknown After November 1962 all US Navy aircraft designations were simplified, thus A4D-1 became A-4A. ………………………………………………………………….... A4D-1/A-4A 142234 was accepted by the US Navy on July 26, 1957. Spent three years with the US Marine Corps in California then Japan before being shipped back home to become a Naval Air Reserve trainer from three California located Navy bases until 1963 when it was stored at NAF Litchfield Park compound in the Arizona desert. In 1965 USAF & USN storage was consolidated into one organization so it got moved to MASDC next to Davis-Monthan AFB near Tucson. Returned to service in 1966 again as a Reserve trainer based in Illinois it lasted until 1968 when Struck Off Charge, ending up salvaged at a Florida Naval air base. Another version of the SDASMA ‘Flickr’ pic with A4D-1 142234 may be viewed here: www.millionmonkeytheater.com/a4dpics/142234.jpg www.millionmonkeytheater.com/A4D.html ………………………………………………………………….... The US Navy accepted A4D-1 142146 on March 11, 1957. Spent two to three years with the US Marine Corps in California and Japan before returning home to fly as a Naval Air Reserve trainer from three California located Navy air bases until a sudden and tragic demise. October 1, 1961 Captain Leroy Mathews was killed when his A4D-1 BuNo 142146 code 6G of NAS Alameda crashed in the High Sierras north of Bass Lake in the Strawberry Mine area while on a tactical flight from NAS Alameda a4skyhawk.org/3e/alameda/alameda.htm a4skyhawk.org/3e/alameda/nartu.htm a4skyhawk.org/?q=3e/alameda/142146-crash-1.htm a4skyhawk.org/?q=3e/alameda/142146-crash-2.htm (Information courtesy the ‘A-4 Skyhawk Association’) My respect to the pilot his family and friends ………………………………………………………………….... A4D-1/A-4A 142168 was accepted by the US Navy on March 18, 1957. Spent three years with the US Marine Corps in both California and Japan before being shipped home with the USMC to later become a Naval Air Reserve trainer from three California based Navy air stations until 1963, then stored at the desert compound of NAF Litchfield Park Arizona. USAF & USN storage was combined in 1965 into one organization so it was moved on to MASDC near Tucson. Returned to service in 1966 again as a Reserve trainer based in Minnesota and Texas it lasted until 1968 when Struck Off Charge - yet not scrapped. It was recorded at Memphis Naval Air Technical Training Center as an instructional airframe on October 21, 1975. The cockpit section of A-4A 142168 was acquired in July 1999 by the ‘Combat Air Museum’ in Topeka, Kansas as a static exhibit. Still US Government Property, its remains are officially on loan from the National Museum of Naval Aviation Pensacola. The major portions of this aircraft are probably scrapped. Luckily there are some nice early images of A4D-1/A-4A 142168 via the internet courtesy of the ‘A-4 Skyhawk Association’: a4skyhawk.org/content/142168-vma-224-douglas-aircraft-335 A4D-1 142168 VMA-224 Modex: WK-7 Date: April 9, 1957 Photo Credit: Douglas Aircraft right side in-flight view of Bengals Skyhawk BuNo 142155, WK-4, and BuNo 142168, WK-7, in flight over southern California a4skyhawk.org/content/142168-vma-224-douglas-aircraft-336 A4D-1 142168 VMA-224 Modex: WK-7 Date: April 9, 1957 Photo Credit: Douglas Aircraft Left rear in-flight view of Bengals Skyhawk BuNo 142155, WK-4, and BuNo 142168, WK-7, in flight over southern California a4skyhawk.org/content/142168-vma-224-douglas-aircraft-337 A4D-1 142168 VMA-224 Modex: WK-7 Date: April 9, 1957 Photo Credit: Douglas Aircraft Right side in-flight view of Bengals Skyhawk BuNo 142168, WK-7, in flight over southern California And a fine color profile of A4D-1 142168 created from the above images: wp.scn.ru/en/ww3/a/783/3/2 img.wp.scn.ru/camms/ar/783/pics/3_87.png A-4A (A4D-1) Unit: VMA-224, USMC Serial: 7/WK (BuNo.142168) MCAS El Toro, circa 1957 There are also internet images of its cockpit available to view: a4skyhawk.org/content/142168-combat-air-museum-museum-pho... TA-4A 142168 Construction Number: 11422 Cockpit on display at Combat Air Museum, Forbes Field/AFB Topeka, Kansas www.airliners.net/photo/USA---Navy/Douglas-A-4A-Skyhawk/0... www.myaviation.net/search/photo_search.php?id=00468196 Cockpit view of Douglas A-4A 142168 Skyhawk at Topeka - Forbes Field (FOE / KFOE): USA - Kansas, September 3, 2005
